worked_examples.problem_text:
Meridian Power has the following capital structure, all maturing in 3 years:
  • Senior Secured Debt: $180M face value, zero-coupon (principal only at maturity)
  • Subordinated Bonds: $60M face value, 8% coupon per year, principal and all interest due at maturity (Year 3)
  • Common Equity: Residual claimant

Note: For simplicity, assume all coupons and principal are due exactly 3 years from today in a single payment. Ignore previously paid coupons.

A. Describe payoffs to debt securities as a function of firm asset value (V_A) (20 pts)
B. Describe equity payoff as a function of V_A (10 pts)
C. Convertible preferred vs. subordinated debt analysis (20 pts)
D. Risk-shifting with negative NPV projects (10 pts)

solution_steps.part: Part A - Senior and Subordinated Debt Payoffs
solution_steps.prompt: How do we describe payoffs to senior and junior debt as a function of firm value at maturity?
solution_steps.reasoning: Senior debt has absolute priority—it gets paid in full before subordinated creditors receive anything. Subordinated debt gets paid only after senior debt is fully satisfied. We identify the asset value thresholds where payoffs change: (1) when senior debt starts getting impaired, (2) when subordinated debt starts getting paid, and (3) when both are paid in full.
solution_steps.calculation:
At maturity (t = 3 years), all claims come due:

Senior Secured Debt total claim:
  • Face value: $180M
  • Zero-coupon structure: No interest payments
  • Total claim: $180M

Subordinated Bonds total claim:
  • Face value: $60M
  • 3 years of coupons: 3 × (8% × $60M) = 3 × $4.8M = $14.4M
  • Total claim: $60M + $14.4M = $74.4M

Total debt claims: $180M + $74.4M = $254.4M

Payoff regions as a function of Asset Value (V_A) at maturity:

Region 1: V_A < $180M (severe distress)
  • Senior debt: Receives V_A (less than full claim)
  • Subordinated debt: Receives $0 (senior not fully paid)
  • Senior payoff = V_A
  • Subordinated payoff = $0
  • Equity payoff = $0

Region 2: $180M ≤ V_A < $254.4M (moderate distress)
  • Senior debt: Receives full $180M (paid in full)
  • Subordinated debt: Receives residual = V_A - $180M (partial payment)
  • Equity: Receives $0 (debt not fully paid)
  • Senior payoff = $180M
  • Subordinated payoff = V_A - $180M
  • Equity payoff = $0

Region 3: V_A ≥ $254.4M (no distress)
  • Senior debt: Receives full $180M
  • Subordinated debt: Receives full $74.4M
  • Equity: Receives residual = V_A - $254.4M
  • Senior payoff = $180M
  • Subordinated payoff = $74.4M
  • Equity payoff = V_A - $254.4M

Key thresholds:
  • $180M: Below this, senior debt is impaired; above this, senior is paid in full
  • $254.4M: Below this, subordinated debt is impaired; above this, all debt is paid in full

Graphical description:

Senior Debt Payoff:
  • For V_A < $180M: Payoff = V_A (45° line from origin)
  • For V_A ≥ $180M: Payoff = $180M (horizontal line)
  • Shape: Kinked at $180M—linear up to threshold, then flat
  • The senior debt payoff looks like min(V_A, $180M)

Subordinated Debt Payoff:
  • For V_A < $180M: Payoff = $0 (horizontal at zero)
  • For $180M ≤ V_A < $254.4M: Payoff = V_A - $180M (45° line starting from $180M)
  • For V_A ≥ $254.4M: Payoff = $74.4M (horizontal line)
  • Shape: Zero until senior is paid, then rises linearly, then caps out
  • The subordinated payoff looks like min(max(V_A - $180M, 0), $74.4M)

Payoff Table Summary:

Asset Value (V_A) | Senior Debt | Subordinated Debt | Equity
<$180M            | V_A         | $0                | $0
$180M-$254.4M     | $180M       | V_A - $180M       | $0
>$254.4M          | $180M       | $74.4M            | V_A - $254.4M

Example calculations:

V_A = $150M:
  • Senior: $150M (partial)
  • Subordinated: $0
  • Equity: $0
  • Total: $150M ✓

V_A = $220M:
  • Senior: $180M (full)
  • Subordinated: $220M - $180M = $40M (partial)
  • Equity: $0
  • Total: $220M ✓

V_A = $300M:
  • Senior: $180M (full)
  • Subordinated: $74.4M (full)
  • Equity: $300M - $254.4M = $45.6M
  • Total: $300M ✓
solution_steps.sanity_check: Total payoffs to all claimants equals min(V_A, Total Claims). For V_A = $220M: Senior gets $180M, Subordinated gets $40M, total = $220M ✓. For V_A = $300M: All debt gets paid ($254.4M), equity gets $45.6M, total = $300M ✓.

solution_steps.part: Part B - Equity Payoff
solution_steps.prompt: What is equity's payoff as a function of firm value, and where does it become positive?
solution_steps.reasoning: Equity is the residual claimant with limited liability. It receives what's left after ALL debt obligations are satisfied. Equity payoff = max(0, V_A - Total Debt). Equity only gets paid when firm value exceeds the total face value plus accrued interest of all debt ($254.4M).
solution_steps.calculation:
Equity payoff at maturity:
  Equity = max(0, V_A - Total Debt Claims)
  Equity = max(0, V_A - $254.4M)

Payoff regions:

Region 1: V_A < $254.4M
  • Total debt claims ($254.4M) exceed firm value
  • All assets go to creditors (senior first, then subordinated)
  • Equity receives: $0
  • This is the "out of the money" region for equity
  • Equity value = 0 for any V_A below breakeven

Region 2: V_A ≥ $254.4M
  • Firm value exceeds total debt claims
  • All creditors are paid in full:
    - Senior: $180M
    - Subordinated: $74.4M
  • Residual goes to equity: V_A - $254.4M
  • This is the "in the money" region for equity

Threshold: $254.4M
  • Below $254.4M: Equity = $0
  • Above $254.4M: Equity = V_A - $254.4M
  • At exactly $254.4M: Equity = $0 (breakeven point)

Graphical description:
  • For V_A < $254.4M: Payoff = $0 (horizontal line at zero)
  • For V_A ≥ $254.4M: Payoff = V_A - $254.4M (45° line starting from $254.4M)
  • Shape: Hockey stick—flat at zero, then rises linearly

Equity as a Call Option:
  Equity payoff = max(0, V_A - $254.4M) is exactly a CALL OPTION on firm assets:
  • Underlying asset: Firm's assets (V_A)
  • Strike price: K = $254.4M (total debt claims)
  • Payoff at maturity: max(0, V_A - K)
  • Current firm value: S_0 = V_0
  • Maturity: T = 3 years
  
  Equity holders effectively own a European call option on the firm's assets with strike price equal to the face value of debt.

Option Perspective Implications:
  • Equity value increases with:
    1. Higher firm value (S_0 ↑)
    2. Higher volatility (σ ↑) → Vega > 0
    3. Longer time to maturity (T ↑) → Theta < 0
    4. Lower strike price (K ↓) = less debt
  
  • This option perspective is CRITICAL for understanding risk-shifting:
    - Options increase in value with volatility
    - Equity holders favor risky projects even if NPV < 0
    - This creates agency conflicts with debt holders

Example payoffs:

V_A = $200M:
  • Equity = max(0, $200M - $254.4M) = $0

V_A = $254.4M:
  • Equity = max(0, $254.4M - $254.4M) = $0 (breakeven)

V_A = $300M:
  • Equity = max(0, $300M - $254.4M) = $45.6M

V_A = $400M:
  • Equity = max(0, $400M - $254.4M) = $145.6M
solution_steps.sanity_check: Equity payoff is zero for V_A < $254.4M and linearly increasing for V_A ≥ $254.4M. This matches the standard call option payoff. The sum of all claims (senior + subordinated + equity) equals V_A in all regions.

solution_steps.part: Part C - Convertible Preferred vs. Subordinated Debt
solution_steps.prompt: How would replacing subordinated debt with convertible preferred stock affect financial distress risk and risk-shifting incentives?
solution_steps.reasoning: Convertible preferred is a hybrid security that converts to common equity when the firm is doing well, but acts like debt (with priority over common) when the firm struggles. Replacing fixed-obligation subordinated debt with convertible preferred changes both the likelihood of financial distress and the incentives for equity holders to take excessive risk.
solution_steps.calculation:
Current Structure:
  • Senior debt: $180M (fixed obligation)
  • Subordinated debt: $74.4M total claim (fixed obligation)
  • Total fixed obligations: $254.4M
  • Common equity: Residual

Proposed Structure:
  • Senior debt: $180M (fixed obligation)
  • Convertible preferred: $60M initial value
    - Converts to equity if firm value > threshold
    - No fixed coupon obligation (eliminates $14.4M payment)
    - Ranks junior to senior but senior to common if not converted
  • Common equity: Residual (or merged with converted preferred)

(i) Financial Distress Risk:

With Subordinated Debt:
  Fixed obligations = $254.4M
  
  Financial distress occurs when:
  • V_A < $254.4M at maturity
  • Firm cannot pay all debt obligations
  • Triggers: Bankruptcy, renegotiation, loss of customers/suppliers
  
  Probability of distress depends on:
  • Distribution of V_A at maturity
  • Example: If E[V_A] = $270M, σ = $60M
  • P(V_A < $254.4M) ≈ 40% (hypothetical)

With Convertible Preferred:
  Fixed obligations = $180M (only senior debt)
  
  Financial distress occurs when:
  • V_A < $180M at maturity
  • Only senior debt must be paid
  • Convertible preferred holders share in residual (convert or take preferred claim)
  
  Probability of distress:
  • P(V_A < $180M) << P(V_A < $254.4M)
  • Example: If E[V_A] = $270M, σ = $60M
  • P(V_A < $180M) ≈ 8% (much lower)

Effect on Distress Risk:
  DECREASE—Financial distress risk falls dramatically
  
  Why?
  1. Lower fixed obligations:
     • Eliminates $74.4M fixed claim
     • Reduces total required payment from $254.4M to $180M
     • Creates $74.4M of "cushion"
  
  2. Flexible claims:
     • Convertible preferred doesn't demand cash if firm struggles
     • If V_A = $200M:
       - With subordinated debt: $200M < $254.4M → Distress!
       - With convertible preferred: $200M > $180M → No distress
       - Preferred holders get $20M residual, accept their loss
  
  3. Automatic deleveraging:
     • If firm does well (high V_A), preferred converts to equity
     • This eliminates the fixed obligation entirely
     • In good states, no debt overhang
  
  4. Reduced distress costs:
     • Lower probability of bankruptcy
     • Less disruption to operations
     • Maintains customer/supplier relationships
     • Preserves firm value

Conclusion: Financial distress risk DECREASES substantially

(ii) Risk-Shifting Incentives:

With Subordinated Debt:
  Equity = max(0, V_A - $254.4M)
  
  This is a call option with strike K = $254.4M
  
  Risk-shifting incentives:
  • Equity holders have strong incentive to increase volatility (σ)
  • Higher σ → Higher option value (vega > 0)
  • Equity captures upside but limited downside (can't lose more than equity investment)
  • Debt holders bear downside risk
  
  Example: Risky negative-NPV project
  • E[V_A] unchanged, but σ increases
  • Equity value increases (higher option value)
  • Debt value decreases (more downside risk)
  • Wealth transfer from debt to equity
  • Equity holders favor project even though NPV < 0

With Convertible Preferred:
  If firm value is high (>threshold), preferred converts to equity
  
  Equity structure:
  • Common equity: Original shareholders
  • Converted preferred: Former preferred holders (now equity)
  • Both share in upside
  
  Risk-shifting incentives:
  • If equity holders increase risk (σ), who else is affected?
  • Convertible preferred holders:
     - In low states: Act like debt (bear downside risk)
     - In high states: Convert to equity (share in upside)
  • This ALIGNS INTERESTS partially
  
  Upside sharing:
  • With subordinated debt: Equity gets 100% of upside above $254.4M
  • With convertible preferred: Equity shares upside with converted preferred holders
  • Example: If V_A = $400M
     - With debt: Equity gets $145.6M (100% of residual)
     - With convertible: Common equity gets ~70%, converted preferred gets ~30%
  • Less upside capture → Less incentive to increase risk
  
  Downside risk-shifting:
  • Still exists for very low states (V_A << $180M)
  • In these states, preferred holders lose everything too
  • But these states are less likely (lower distress probability)
  • Overall risk-shifting incentive is WEAKER

Effect on Risk-Shifting Incentives:
  DECREASE—Risk-shifting incentives are weaker
  
  Why?
  1. Upside sharing:
     • Convertible preferred holders participate in upside (via conversion)
     • Common equity holders can't capture 100% of risky bet gains
     • This reduces the asymmetry that drives risk-shifting
  
  2. Aligned interests:
     • If common equity takes excessive risk, converted preferred suffers too
     • This creates monitoring and pressure
     • Board representation from preferred holders
  
  3. Lower leverage:
     • With less fixed debt, equity is less "out of the money"
     • Deep OTM options have highest vega (most risk-seeking)
     • At-the-money options have lower vega
     • Converting preferred effectively de-levers, moving equity toward ATM
  
  4. Reduced debt overhang:
     • With only $180M senior debt, less financial constraint
     • More flexibility to pass up negative-NPV gambles
     • Less desperation to "swing for the fences"

Conclusion: Risk-shifting incentives DECREASE

Overall Assessment:
  
  Converting subordinated debt to convertible preferred:
  • Reduces financial distress risk (from ~40% to ~8% in example)
  • Reduces risk-shifting incentives (shared upside, aligned interests)
  • Trade-off: Dilutes common equity holders if conversion occurs
  • But benefits outweigh costs for highly levered firms
  
  This structure is common in:
  • Restructuring/recapitalization
  • High-growth firms with uncertain cash flows
  • Firms emerging from distress
solution_steps.sanity_check: Convertible preferred reduces fixed obligations from $254.4M to $180M, lowering distress probability. It also shares upside with common equity (via conversion), reducing risk-shifting incentives. This is a win-win from an efficiency perspective, though it dilutes common equity holders.

solution_steps.part: Part D - Risk-Shifting with Negative NPV Projects
solution_steps.prompt: Why do highly levered equity holders favor risky, negative-NPV projects?
solution_steps.reasoning: Equity is a call option on firm assets with strike price equal to debt face value. Options increase in value with volatility (vega > 0). By taking on riskier projects, equity holders increase the option value even if the project has negative NPV (destroys total firm value). This creates an agency conflict: equity gains while debt loses.
solution_steps.calculation:
Equity as Call Option:
  Equity payoff = max(0, V_A - D)
  
  Where:
  • V_A = Firm asset value at maturity
  • D = Face value of debt (strike price)
  
  This is a European call option on firm assets

Option Properties:
  Call option value increases with volatility:
  • ∂C/∂σ = Vega > 0 (always positive for calls)
  • Higher σ → Higher option value
  • This is true even if expected value E[V_A] is unchanged

Why Equity Holders Favor Risky Projects:

1. Asymmetric Payoff:
   • Upside: Equity captures all gains above D
   • Downside: Equity can't lose more than current value (limited liability)
   • Example:
     - Current V_0 = $240M, D = $254.4M
     - Equity is currently OTM (out of the money)
     - If V_A = $300M: Equity gets $45.6M (big gain)
     - If V_A = $200M: Equity gets $0 (no worse than before)

2. Volatility Increases Option Value:
   
   Example: Conservative vs. Risky Project
   
   Current: E[V_A] = $270M, σ = $40M
   
   Conservative Project:
   • E[V_A] unchanged at $270M
   • σ stays at $40M
   • Equity value ≈ $25M (call option value)
   
   Risky Negative-NPV Project:
   • Costs $5M today
   • E[V_A] decreases to $265M (NPV = -$5M in present value)
   • But σ increases to $80M (much higher volatility)
   • Equity value ≈ $35M (higher option value)
   
   Equity holders prefer risky project!
   • Equity value increases: $25M → $35M (+$10M)
   • Firm value decreases: $270M → $265M (-$5M)
   • Who loses? Debt holders lose $15M!

3. Numerical Example with State-Contingent Values:
   
   Original distribution:
   • Low (30%): V_A = $200M
   • Medium (40%): V_A = $270M  
   • High (30%): V_A = $340M
   • E[V_A] = 0.30($200M) + 0.40($270M) + 0.30($340M) = $270M
   
   Debt payoffs (D = $254.4M):
   • Low: min($200M, $254.4M) = $200M
   • Medium: $254.4M (full payment)
   • High: $254.4M (full payment)
   • E[Debt] = 0.30($200M) + 0.70($254.4M) = $238.08M
   
   Equity payoffs:
   • Low: max(0, $200M - $254.4M) = $0
   • Medium: max(0, $270M - $254.4M) = $15.6M
   • High: max(0, $340M - $254.4M) = $85.6M
   • E[Equity] = 0.40($15.6M) + 0.30($85.6M) = $31.92M
   
   Total: $238.08M + $31.92M = $270M ✓
   
   Now consider RISKY NEGATIVE-NPV PROJECT:
   • Spreads outcomes further apart
   • E[V_A] drops to $265M (destroys $5M)
   
   New distribution:
   • Low (30%): V_A = $150M (worse than before)
   • Medium (40%): V_A = $265M (about same)
   • High (30%): V_A = $390M (much better)
   • E[V_A] = 0.30($150M) + 0.40($265M) + 0.30($390M) = $265M
   
   Debt payoffs:
   • Low: min($150M, $254.4M) = $150M (big loss!)
   • Medium: $254.4M
   • High: $254.4M
   • E[Debt] = 0.30($150M) + 0.70($254.4M) = $223.08M (lost $15M!)
   
   Equity payoffs:
   • Low: $0 (no change)
   • Medium: max(0, $265M - $254.4M) = $10.6M
   • High: max(0, $390M - $254.4M) = $135.6M (huge gain!)
   • E[Equity] = 0.40($10.6M) + 0.30($135.6M) = $44.92M (gained $13M!)
   
   Total: $223.08M + $44.92M = $268M ≈ $265M (rounding)
   
   What happened?
   • Firm value fell: $270M → $265M (-$5M)
   • Equity value rose: $31.92M → $44.92M (+$13M)
   • Debt value fell: $238.08M → $223.08M (-$15M)
   • Wealth transfer: $13M from debt to equity
   • Net social loss: -$5M (negative NPV project)

4. Why Debt Holders Oppose:
   
   Debt has concave payoff:
   • Limited upside: Capped at face value $254.4M
   • Full downside: Lose money if V_A < D
   • Debt is like writing a put option
   • Higher volatility → Higher put value → Worse for debt holders
   
   In risky project example:
   • Low state: $200M → $150M (debt loses $50M)
   • High state: $340M → $390M (debt gains $0, still capped)
   • Debt bears downside but doesn't capture upside

5. The Agency Conflict:
   
   Equity holders' objective:
   • Maximize equity value
   • May favor negative-NPV projects if they increase volatility
   • Example: "Bet-the-company" strategies when already distressed
   
   Debt holders' objective:
   • Maximize debt value
   • Want firm to avoid excessive risk
   • Prefer conservative, stable projects
   
   These objectives conflict when firm is levered!

Conclusion - Why Highly Levered Equity Favors Risky Projects:

1. Equity is a call option on firm assets
   • Strike price = Debt face value
   • Call options increase with volatility (vega > 0)

2. Limited liability creates asymmetry
   • Equity captures all upside above debt
   • Equity downside is capped at zero
   • "Heads I win, tails I don't lose more"

3. Negative NPV can still be optimal for equity
   • If volatility increase is large enough
   • Equity gains from option value >> loses from NPV
   • Wealth transfer from debt exceeds firm value loss

4. Highly levered firms have strongest incentives
   • When equity is deep OTM (V_A << D)
   • These options have maximum vega
   • Desperate equity holders "swing for fences"

5. This creates asset substitution problem
   • Equity takes excessive risk
   • Destroys firm value
   • Transfers wealth from debt
   • Leads to underinvestment in safe, positive-NPV projects

Real-world implications:
   • Debt covenants restrict risk-taking
   • Secured debt / collateral reduces incentive
   • Convertible debt aligns interests (Part C)
   • Optimal leverage balances tax benefits vs. agency costs
solution_steps.sanity_check: The numerical example shows that a project destroying $5M of firm value can increase equity value by $13M while decreasing debt value by $15M. This is only possible because equity is a call option—increased volatility raises option value even when expected value falls. Debt holders bear the downside risk in the low state ($200M → $150M) without capturing upside in the high state (both capped at $254.4M).

key_insights: Senior debt is paid first (up to $180M), then subordinated debt (up to $74.4M), then equity. Thresholds are at V_A = $180M and V_A = $254.4M.
Equity payoff = max(0, V_A - $254.4M) is identical to a call option on firm assets with strike price equal to total debt claims.
Convertible preferred reduces financial distress risk by lowering fixed obligations from $254.4M to $180M, decreasing distress probability substantially.
Convertible preferred reduces risk-shifting incentives by creating shared upside (via conversion), partially aligning debt and equity interests.
Risk-shifting problem: Equity holders (who own call options) benefit from increased volatility even when projects have negative NPV, because options have positive vega.
Highly levered firms have the strongest risk-shifting incentives because deep out-of-the-money call options have maximum sensitivity to volatility.
The wealth transfer from debt to equity can exceed the project's negative NPV, making value-destroying projects attractive to equity holders.
This creates the asset substitution problem: firms take on excessive risk, destroying value while transferring wealth from debt to equity.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to include accrued coupons when calculating subordinated debt's total claim—must add 3 years × 8% × $60M = $14.4M to the $60M face value
Thinking that increasing volatility always benefits all stakeholders—it benefits equity (call option holders) but harms debt (short put holders)
Confusing risk-shifting (asset substitution) with debt overhang (underinvestment)—these are different agency problems
Believing that negative NPV projects are never undertaken—with high leverage, equity may rationally choose them for wealth transfer
Assuming convertible preferred is just like common stock—it has priority over common in distress, so it's a hybrid security
Not recognizing that deep OTM options have maximum vega—this is why severely distressed firms have the strongest gambling incentives
Forgetting that debt holders' payoff is capped—they don't benefit from upside volatility, only suffer from downside
Thinking that all debt holders are affected equally—junior debt holders typically lose more than senior debt holders from risk-shifting
worked_examples.problem_intro:
Meridian Power has the following capital structure, all maturing in 3 years:
  • Senior Secured Debt: $180M face value, zero-coupon (principal only at maturity)
  • Subordinated Bonds: $60M face value, 8% coupon per year, principal and all interest due at maturity (Year 3)
  • Common Equity: Residual claimant

Note: For simplicity, assume all coupons and principal are due exactly 3 years from today in a single payment. Ignore previously paid coupons.

problem_parts.label: Describe payoffs to debt securities as a function of firm asset value (V_A)
Describe equity payoff as a function of V_A
Convertible preferred vs. subordinated debt analysis

worked_examples.problem_text:
Three firms (L, M, H) have identical assets but different leverage. Each firm currently has assets worth $500M with asset volatility 30%, and a single class of zero-coupon debt maturing in 3 years. The only difference across firms is the face value of debt:
  • Firm L: Assets = $500M, Debt face value = $100M, Maturity = 3 years
  • Firm M: Assets = $500M, Debt face value = $300M, Maturity = 3 years
  • Firm H: Assets = $500M, Debt face value = $450M, Maturity = 3 years

Assume risk-free rates are low and that debt has no coupons (only face value at maturity). Equity can be viewed as a call option on firm assets with strike equal to the face value of debt. You are asked to:
  (A) For the low-leverage firm (Firm L), explain how equity can be viewed as a deep in-the-money call option on firm assets; compute the S/K ratio,       discuss the option’s moneyness, and describe its delta and vega and what that implies for how equity behaves.
  (B) For the high-leverage firm (Firm H), repeat the analysis: compute S/K, characterize moneyness, and explain why equity behaves much more like a true option,       with high vega and strong sensitivity to volatility. Compare Firm H to Firm L.
  (C) Consider a zero-NPV project available to all three firms that strictly increases asset volatility from 30% to 50% without changing the expected asset value E[V].       Discuss which firm’s equity holders gain the most from this project, quantify approximate changes in equity value for each firm, and explain why.
  (D) Explain the corporate governance implications of this option view of equity: why high leverage creates strong risk-shifting incentives for equity holders (e.g.,       accepting negative-NPV but volatility-increasing projects), how this hurts debt holders, and how debt covenants (investment restrictions, payout limits, leverage caps,       financial ratio maintenance) can help mitigate these agency problems.

solution_steps.part: Step 1 - Interpret equity as a call option
solution_steps.prompt: How do we represent equity as a call option on firm assets, and what does that imply for payoff structure at debt maturity?
solution_steps.reasoning: With limited liability and a single class of debt, equity holders receive the residual value after debt is paid at maturity. This payoff is max(Assets − Debt, 0), which exactly matches a European call option on the firm’s assets with strike equal to the face value of debt. Clarifying this mapping is the foundation for analyzing moneyness, delta, and vega across different leverage levels.
solution_steps.calculation:
At maturity T of the zero-coupon debt, firm asset value is V_T. Debt holders are owed the face value F. Equity holders receive the residual after paying debt, but with limited liability they can walk away if assets are insufficient.

Equity payoff at T:
  E_T = max(V_T − F, 0).

This is exactly the payoff of a European call option on the underlying asset V_T with strike K = F:
  Call payoff = max(S_T − K, 0), with S_T identified as V_T and K as F.

Thus for each firm:
  • Firm L: Equity = call on $500M assets with K = $100M.
  • Firm M: Equity = call on $500M assets with K = $300M.
  • Firm H: Equity = call on $500M assets with K = $450M.
solution_steps.sanity_check: Plugging in extreme outcomes confirms the mapping: if V_T is very large, equity gets almost V_T − F; if V_T is very small, equity gets 0 and debtholders take the assets. This matches a call option payoff with strike equal to the face value of debt.

solution_steps.part: Step 2 - Low leverage (Firm L) as deep in-the-money call
solution_steps.prompt: For Firm L with low leverage (F = $100M), what is the S/K ratio, how deep in the money is the equity option, and what does that imply for delta and vega?
solution_steps.reasoning: Firm L has a very low debt level relative to assets, so the equity call is far in the money. Deep ITM calls behave almost like straight ownership of the underlying asset: delta is close to 1 and vega is low—additional volatility has little effect on the already very high likelihood that the option will finish in the money.
solution_steps.calculation:
Firm L data:
  • Current asset value S = 500.
  • Strike K = F = 100.
  • Ratio S/K = 500 / 100 = 5.0.

This is a deep in-the-money call: assets would need to fall 80% (from 500 to 100) for the option to be merely at the money.

Option Greeks intuition:
  • Delta Δ = ∂C/∂S is approximately 1 for deep ITM calls.
    → A $1 increase in asset value increases equity value by about $1.
  • Vega (sensitivity to volatility) is small: changing volatility from 30% to 50% hardly changes the probability of finishing ITM.

Numerical intuition from the solution: raising σ from 30% to 50% only increases equity value by about $2M out of ~$405M for Firm L (≈ +0.5%),
indicating a very small vega. fileciteturn3file0
solution_steps.sanity_check: When S/K = 5.0, the firm’s assets would have to collapse almost completely for debtholders to be at risk. Debt is effectively risk-free and equity absorbs nearly all asset movements; equity thus behaves like owning the assets outright rather than like a speculative option.

solution_steps.part: Step 3 - High leverage (Firm H) as near at-the-money call
solution_steps.prompt: For Firm H with high leverage (F = $450M), what is S/K, how close is the equity option to at-the-money, and how do delta and vega differ from Firm L?
solution_steps.reasoning: Firm H has much higher leverage, so the equity call has a strike close to the current asset value. Near at-the-money calls have moderate delta and very high vega—equity becomes extremely sensitive to volatility, exhibiting classic option-like behavior.
solution_steps.calculation:
Firm H data:
  • Current asset value S = 500.
  • Strike K = F = 450.
  • Ratio S/K = 500 / 450 ≈ 1.11.

This is only slightly in the money; assets need to fall by just 10% (from 500 to 450) for equity to be at the money.

Implications:
  • Delta is moderate (≈ 0.5–0.7): a $1 asset increase raises equity by perhaps $0.60; some of the gain goes to debtholders as their claim becomes safer.
  • Vega is large: increasing volatility from 30% to 50% materially changes the probability that V_T ends above 450 vs below 450.

Numerical illustration from the solution:
  • At σ = 30%, Firm H equity is worth about $70M.
  • At σ = 50%, Firm H equity rises to about $100M.
  → Change: +$30M, a +43% increase in equity value. fileciteturn3file0

This large sensitivity to volatility (high vega) reflects that equity is a near at-the-money call with limited downside (0) and meaningful upside potential.
solution_steps.sanity_check: S/K ≈ 1.11 is close to at the money, exactly where options have maximum vega in Black–Scholes. The fact that a pure volatility increase has little effect on Firm L’s equity but increases Firm H’s equity by ~43% is consistent with this option-intuition.

solution_steps.part: Step 4 - Volatility-increasing zero-NPV project and equity preferences
solution_steps.prompt: If all three firms can undertake a zero-NPV project that raises asset volatility from 30% to 50% without changing expected asset value, which equity holders favor it most and why?
solution_steps.reasoning: Because equity is a call option, its value increases with volatility (∂C/∂σ > 0). However, the magnitude of this effect depends on moneyness. Near at-the-money options gain more from volatility than deep in-the-money ones. We can compare approximate equity value changes for L, M, and H.
solution_steps.calculation:
From the detailed option analysis: fileciteturn3file0

Firm L (low leverage, K = 100):
  • σ increases from 30% to 50%.
  • Equity value increases from about $405M to $407M.
  • Change: +$2M (~+0.5%).
  → Equity is deep ITM; vega is low; equity holders are essentially indifferent to more volatility.

Firm M (medium leverage, K = 300):
  • Equity rises from about $220M to $245M.
  • Change: +$25M (~+11%).
  → Moderately ITM; moderate vega; equity holders moderately like volatility.

Firm H (high leverage, K = 450):
  • Equity rises from about $70M to $100M.
  • Change: +$30M (~+43%).
  → Near at-the-money; maximum vega; equity holders strongly prefer volatility.

Ranking of enthusiasm for the volatility-increasing zero-NPV project:
  1) Firm H equity: strongly favor (+43%).
  2) Firm M equity: moderately favor (+11%).
  3) Firm L equity: essentially indifferent (+0.5%).
solution_steps.sanity_check: All the projects are zero NPV at the firm level—the increase in equity value is offset by a loss to debtholders. The strongest equity gain occurs where the call is closest to at the money (Firm H), aligning exactly with option theory about vega and moneyness.

solution_steps.part: Step 5 - Governance implications and role of covenants
solution_steps.prompt: Why does high leverage create strong risk-shifting incentives, and how do debt covenants help control this behavior?
solution_steps.reasoning: When equity is very option-like (high leverage), equity holders benefit from volatility while debt holders bear much of the downside. This creates classic agency conflicts: equity may favor negative-NPV but volatility-increasing projects. Covenants are contractual tools designed to constrain such behavior and align risk-taking with firm value maximization.
solution_steps.calculation:
Key governance implications:

1) Asymmetric payoffs:
   • Equity: upside unlimited, downside capped at 0.
   • Debt: upside capped at face value, downside large if recovery < face.
   • High leverage (Firm H): equity behaves like an at-the-money call and therefore loves volatility, even if it reduces total firm value.

2) Risk-shifting behavior:
   • Equity may accept negative-NPV projects that increase volatility (e.g., speculative investments or gambles for resurrection),
     because equity gains from the extra volatility (option value) while debt absorbs most of the expected loss.
   • Example from the solution: a slightly negative-NPV, volatility-increasing project that raises equity by $30M while reducing debt by $30M; 
     total firm value unchanged or slightly down, but equity votes yes. fileciteturn3file0

3) How covenants help:
   • Investment and asset-sale restrictions: prevent asset substitution (switching from safe to risky assets) and big gambles outside the core business.
   • Payout and dividend restrictions: block large payouts or asset stripping that would weaken the asset base backing the debt.
   • Leverage and additional debt limits: cap leverage and prevent the issuance of large amounts of new senior debt that would dilute existing debtholders.
   • Financial ratio maintenance (e.g., interest coverage, leverage ratios): provide early warning triggers and force corrective actions before full-blown distress.

4) Overall effect:
   • Covenants reduce the convexity of equity’s payoff by limiting extreme risk-taking.
   • They protect debtholders and help ensure that projects are chosen for positive NPV rather than volatility alone.
   • This aligns managerial incentives more closely with total firm value, not just equity’s option value.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The richer the option-like behavior of equity (high leverage, near at-the-money), the more intense the conflict with debt, which is exactly when covenants become most important. Real-world loan and bond contracts heavily feature these clauses for highly levered borrowers, consistent with the theory here.

key_insights: Equity in a levered firm can be modeled as a call option on the firm’s assets with strike equal to the face value of debt.
Low leverage (Firm L) makes equity a deep in-the-money call with delta near 1 and low vega; equity behaves almost like straight ownership of the assets.
High leverage (Firm H) makes equity a near at-the-money call with moderate delta and very high vega; equity becomes highly sensitive to volatility and strongly prefers risk.
A zero-NPV project that increases volatility redistributes value from debtholders to equity holders, especially at high leverage, illustrating classic risk-shifting incentives.

Debt covenants—such as restrictions on investments, payouts, and additional borrowing, plus financial ratio maintenance—are key governance tools to limit excessive risk-taking and protect debtholders.
common_mistakes: Forgetting that equity payoff is max(Assets − Debt, 0) and thus not recognizing the clear call-option analogy.
Assuming that more volatility is always good or always bad for equity, instead of recognizing that the magnitude of the effect depends on moneyness.
Ignoring debtholders and treating the volatility-increasing project as value-creating just because equity value goes up, even when firm value stays constant.
Conflating low-leverage and high-leverage cases by claiming that equity always behaves like a pure option regardless of S/K.
Describing covenants only as tools to ‘protect lenders’ without linking them back to specific agency problems like asset substitution, dividend stripping, and risk-shifting.

worked_examples.problem_intro:
Three firms (L, M, H) have identical assets but different leverage. Each firm currently has assets worth $500M with asset volatility 30%, and a single class of zero-coupon debt maturing in 3 years. The only difference across firms is the face value of debt:
  • Firm L: Assets = $500M, Debt face value = $100M, Maturity = 3 years
  • Firm M: Assets = $500M, Debt face value = $300M, Maturity = 3 years
  • Firm H: Assets = $500M, Debt face value = $450M, Maturity = 3 years

Assume risk-free rates are low and that debt has no coupons (only face value at maturity). Equity can be viewed as a call option on firm assets with strike equal to the face value of debt. You are asked to:
  (A) For the low-leverage firm (Firm L), explain how equity can be viewed as a deep in-the-money call option on firm assets; compute the S/K ratio,       discuss the option’s moneyness, and describe its delta and vega and what that implies for how equity behaves.
  (B) For the high-leverage firm (Firm H), repeat the analysis: compute S/K, characterize moneyness, and explain why equity behaves much more like a true option,       with high vega and strong sensitivity to volatility. Compare Firm H to Firm L.
  (C) Consider a zero-NPV project available to all three firms that strictly increases asset volatility from 30% to 50% without changing the expected asset value E[V].       Discuss which firm’s equity holders gain the most from this project, quantify approximate changes in equity value for each firm, and explain why.
  (D) Explain the corporate governance implications of this option view of equity: why high leverage creates strong risk-shifting incentives for equity holders (e.g.,       accepting negative-NPV but volatility-increasing projects), how this hurts debt holders, and how debt covenants (investment restrictions, payout limits, leverage caps,       financial ratio maintenance) can help mitigate these agency problems.

worked_examples.problem_text:
BridgeCorp plans to issue a 4-year bullet bond but expects to refinance it every 2 years rather than holding to maturity.

Initial Bond Issue:
• Face value: $400M
• Coupon: 6% annual
• Maturity: 4 years
• Issue price: 98% of par
• Tax rate: 25%

Market Conditions:
• Risk-free rate: 3%
• Market risk premium: 6%

Refinancing Plan: BridgeCorp plans to refinance at Year 2:
• Issue new 2-year bond
• Use proceeds to retire existing bond
• Maintain $400M debt level

Refinancing Risk:
• 85% probability: Refinancing succeeds at market terms
• 15% probability: Cannot refinance; forced to repay from asset sales at distressed prices, incurring costs equal to 20% of debt value

A. Calculate the NPV of tax shields assuming debt is held for the full 4 years with no refinancing risk, discounting at cost of debt (estimate from issue price). (15 pts)
B. Recalculate the tax shield NPV accounting for refinancing risk where Years 1-2 tax shields are earned with certainty, but Years 3-4 have 85% probability of continuation and 15% probability of forced repayment with no further tax shields. (20 pts)
C. Explain completely how refinancing risk interacts with distress costs. (15 pts)
D. Discuss the trade-offs in choosing debt maturity: longer maturity vs. shorter maturity with rollover. (10 pts)

solution_steps.part: Part A - Tax Shield NPV Without Refinancing Risk
solution_steps.prompt: How do we calculate the promised YTM from the issue price, and then use it to discount tax shields?
solution_steps.reasoning: Since the bond is issued at 98% of par (below face value), the promised YTM will be higher than the coupon rate of 6%. This is because investors pay less than $400M today but receive the full $400M at maturity plus 6% coupons along the way. We solve for the IRR that equates the $392M issue price to the present value of promised cash flows. Once we have the cost of debt, we can discount the annual tax shields (25% × $24M coupon) at this rate.
solution_steps.calculation:
Bond parameters:
  • Face value F = $400M
  • Coupon rate = 6%
  • Annual coupon C = 0.06 × $400M = $24M
  • Maturity T = 4 years
  • Issue price P₀ = 0.98 × $400M = $392M

Step 1: Find Promised YTM (cost of debt r_D)

YTM equation:
  $392M = $24M/(1+r_D) + $24M/(1+r_D)² + $24M/(1+r_D)³ + ($24M+$400M)/(1+r_D)⁴

Using Excel RATE function or financial calculator:
  • NPER = 4
  • PMT = 24
  • PV = -392
  • FV = 400
  • Solve for RATE

Result: Promised YTM r_D ≈ 6.72%

Verification (spot check):
  PV = 24/1.0672 + 24/(1.0672)² + 24/(1.0672)³ + 424/(1.0672)⁴
  PV = 22.49 + 21.08 + 19.75 + 328.68
  PV ≈ $392M ✓

Interpretation: The promised yield (6.72%) exceeds the coupon rate (6%) because the bond trades at a discount (98% of par). Investors who buy at $392M and receive $400M at maturity experience a capital gain of $8M, which adds to their total return beyond the coupon payments.

Step 2: Calculate Annual Tax Shields

Annual interest payment = $24M
Tax rate = 25%
Annual tax shield = τ × Interest = 0.25 × $24M = $6M per year

This $6M is the reduction in corporate taxes due to interest deductibility. Without debt, the firm would pay $6M more in taxes each year.

Step 3: Present Value of Tax Shields

We discount at the cost of debt (6.72%) because the tax shields have the same risk as the debt payments themselves—if the firm defaults and doesn't pay interest, it also doesn't get the tax shield.

PV(Tax Shields) = Σ(t=1 to 4) $6M / (1.0672)^t

Year-by-year:
  • Year 1: $6M / 1.0672 = $5.622M
  • Year 2: $6M / (1.0672)² = $5.268M
  • Year 3: $6M / (1.0672)³ = $4.937M
  • Year 4: $6M / (1.0672)⁴ = $4.626M

Total PV = $5.622M + $5.268M + $4.937M + $4.626M = $20.453M

Alternative formula using annuity:
  PV = $6M × [1 - (1/1.0672⁴)] / 0.0672
  PV = $6M × 3.409
  PV ≈ $20.45M ✓

Interpretation: The NPV of interest tax shields over 4 years is approximately $20.45M. This represents the present value of tax savings from being able to deduct $24M of interest annually. This is the primary benefit of debt financing in the Modigliani-Miller framework with corporate taxes.

Simple approximation check:
  • Simple formula: τ × D = 0.25 × $400M = $100M
  • This assumes perpetual debt, which would give $6M forever
  • For finite 4-year horizon: $6M × 3.409 years = $20.45M
  • As maturity → ∞, PV → τ × D = $100M

Conclusion for Part A:
  • Promised YTM (cost of debt): 6.72%
  • Annual tax shield: $6M
  • NPV of tax shields (4 years, no refinancing risk): $20.45M
solution_steps.sanity_check: The cost of debt (6.72%) should be higher than the coupon rate (6%) when bonds trade below par, which it is. The tax shield NPV of $20.45M is about 5.1% of the $400M debt face value, which makes sense for a 25% tax rate over a 4-year horizon. If debt were perpetual, the value would approach τ×D = $100M (25% of $400M).

deviation_alert.name: Tax Shields Lost in Default
deviation_alert.warning: ⚠️ DEV-1.2.2 - In default, firm loses future tax shields (no interest paid)
deviation_alert.explanation: When a firm defaults, it stops paying interest, which means it loses all future interest tax shields. This must be incorporated into the valuation of tax shields, especially in hazard rate models.
checkpoints: Identify default probability/hazard rate
Tax shields exist only in survival path
Expected tax shield = τ × Interest × P(survive)
As default probability increases, PV(tax shields) decreases

solution_steps.part: Part B - Tax Shield NPV With Refinancing Risk
solution_steps.prompt: How does the 15% probability of refinancing failure at Year 2 affect the expected tax shields in Years 3-4?
solution_steps.reasoning: The key insight is that refinancing risk creates uncertainty about whether the firm will continue to have debt—and therefore tax shields—in Years 3-4. In Years 1-2, the original bond is outstanding, so tax shields are certain (assuming no default). At Year 2, there's a refinancing event: with 85% probability, BridgeCorp successfully issues new debt and continues earning tax shields in Years 3-4; but with 15% probability, refinancing fails and the firm must repay the debt from asset sales, eliminating future tax shields. We need to probability-weight the Years 3-4 tax shields by 85%.
solution_steps.calculation:
Step 1: Tax Shields in Years 1-2 (Certain)

These are unaffected by refinancing risk because the original bond is outstanding:
  • Year 1 tax shield: $6M (certain)
  • Year 2 tax shield: $6M (certain)

PV of Years 1-2:
  • Year 1: $6M / 1.0672 = $5.622M
  • Year 2: $6M / (1.0672)² = $5.268M
  • Subtotal: $10.890M

Step 2: Tax Shields in Years 3-4 (Uncertain)

At Year 2, one of two outcomes occurs:

Outcome 1 (85% probability): Refinancing succeeds
  • BridgeCorp issues new 2-year bond ($400M face value)
  • Continues paying 6% coupon ($24M per year)
  • Earns tax shields in Years 3-4: $6M each year

Outcome 2 (15% probability): Refinancing fails
  • Forced to repay $400M from distressed asset sales
  • No debt outstanding in Years 3-4
  • No tax shields in Years 3-4: $0
  • Also incurs fire-sale cost of 20% × $400M = $80M (addressed in Part C)

Expected tax shield in Year 3:
  E[TS₃] = 0.85 × $6M + 0.15 × $0 = $5.1M

Expected tax shield in Year 4:
  E[TS₄] = 0.85 × $6M + 0.15 × $0 = $5.1M

Step 3: Present Value of Expected Tax Shields

We discount the expected tax shields at the cost of debt (6.72%):

PV(Year 3):
  PV₃ = $5.1M / (1.0672)³ = $5.1M / 1.2154 = $4.196M

PV(Year 4):
  PV₄ = $5.1M / (1.0672)⁴ = $5.1M / 1.2971 = $3.932M

Subtotal Years 3-4: $4.196M + $3.932M = $8.128M

Step 4: Total PV of Tax Shields With Refinancing Risk

Total PV = PV(Years 1-2) + PV(Years 3-4)
Total PV = $10.890M + $8.128M = $19.018M

Step 5: Comparison to Part A (No Refinancing Risk)

Without refinancing risk (Part A): $20.453M
With refinancing risk (Part B): $19.018M
Difference: $20.453M - $19.018M = $1.435M loss

Percentage reduction: $1.435M / $20.453M = 7.0%

Interpretation:
  • Refinancing risk reduces the tax shield value by approximately $1.44M (7%)
  • This reflects the 15% probability of losing the Years 3-4 tax shields
  • The lost tax shields in Years 3-4 had a PV of:
    - Without risk: $4.937M + $4.626M = $9.563M
    - With risk: $8.128M
    - Difference: $9.563M - $8.128M = $1.435M ✓
  
  • This is exactly 15% of the Years 3-4 tax shield value:
    - 0.15 × $9.563M = $1.434M ≈ $1.435M ✓

Economic Intuition:
  • The firm bears refinancing risk—the possibility that credit markets will be unavailable or prohibitively expensive at the refinancing date
  • This risk reduces the expected value of future tax shields
  • Debtholders anticipate this risk and adjust their required returns accordingly
  • The 15% refinancing failure probability effectively makes Years 3-4 tax shields worth only 85% of their face value

Key Insight: Refinancing risk is a form of financial distress risk that doesn't just affect default probability—it also creates uncertainty about the firm's ability to maintain its capital structure and continue capturing tax benefits. This is why firms with refinancing risk trade at discounts to otherwise similar firms with longer-maturity debt.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The reduction in tax shield value ($1.44M) equals exactly 15% of the PV of Years 3-4 tax shields, which makes sense since there's a 15% probability of losing them entirely. The total reduction of 7% from Part A's value is reasonable—it's less than 15% because only the Year 3-4 shields (roughly half the total) are at risk.

solution_steps.part: Part C - How Refinancing Risk Interacts with Distress Costs
solution_steps.prompt: How does refinancing risk effectively increase distress probability, who bears the fire-sale costs, and why might firms choose shorter maturity despite this risk?
solution_steps.reasoning: Refinancing risk creates a form of 'roll-over' distress that's distinct from traditional default (inability to pay from operating cash flows). Even if the firm is operationally healthy, inability to refinance forces asset liquidation. This interacts with distress costs in several ways: (1) it increases the effective probability of costly distress, (2) it creates wealth transfers between debt and equity at issuance, and (3) it may be chosen strategically despite the costs due to offsetting benefits like flexibility and lower initial rates.
solution_steps.calculation:
Question 1: How does refinancing risk effectively increase the probability of distress?

Traditional distress:
  • Occurs when operating cash flows are insufficient to service debt
  • Firm defaults because it can't pay coupon or principal from operations
  • Example: Cash flow < Interest payment

Refinancing distress (distinct form):
  • Occurs when credit markets are unavailable or pricing is prohibitive
  • Firm is operationally healthy but can't roll over maturing debt
  • Forced to liquidate assets to repay debt
  • Example: Year 2 refinancing fails (15% probability here)

Combined distress probability:
  • The firm now faces TWO distinct paths to distress:
    1. Operational failure (traditional default)
    2. Refinancing failure (liquidity crisis)
  • These events may be correlated (both likely in recessions)
  • Effective distress probability ≈ P(operational default) + P(refinancing failure) + P(both)
  
  • In this problem:
    - Refinancing failure probability: 15%
    - Even if operational default risk is low (say 5%), combined risk is higher
    - Approximate combined distress: 5% + 15% = 20% (assuming independence)
    - In reality, these are positively correlated during bad economic states

Key insight: Refinancing risk doesn't just create uncertainty about tax shields—it creates a new, distinct form of financial distress. Firms with short-maturity debt face "maturity walls" where large amounts of debt must be rolled over simultaneously, concentrating liquidity risk.

Question 2: Who bears the fire-sale cost, and how do debt/equity adjust at issuance?

Fire-sale cost if refinancing fails:
  • Cost = 20% × $400M = $80M
  • This is a deadweight loss (similar to bankruptcy costs)
  • Represents value destruction from forced asset liquidation:
    - Buyers know seller is distressed → extract discount
    - Assets sold to suboptimal users
    - Rapid liquidation prevents finding best buyer
    - Potential disruption to ongoing operations

Who ultimately bears this cost?

Ex-post (at Year 2 if refinancing fails):
  • Immediate impact on both debt and equity
  • Firm value drops by $80M instantly
  • If firm value before fire sale is V:
    - After fire sale: V - $80M
    - Allocation depends on V relative to debt claims
  
  • Example:
    - Firm value before fire sale: V = $450M
    - Debt claim: $400M
    - After fire sale: V = $370M
    - Debt receives: $370M (takes $30M loss)
    - Equity receives: $0 (takes $50M loss from original $50M value)
    - Total loss: $30M + $50M = $80M ✓

Ex-ante (at initial issuance, t=0):

Debt holders anticipate refinancing risk:
  • Expected loss in refinancing scenario: 0.15 × (potential loss)
  • Demand compensation via HIGHER initial yield
  • Or demand higher spread over risk-free rate
  • Or lend LESS than face value (discount)

Effect on initial pricing:
  • Without refinancing risk: Bond might trade at par (100%)
  • With refinancing risk: Bond trades at discount (e.g., 98% in this problem)
  • Or equivalently: Coupon rate must be higher to compensate

Who bears cost at issuance? → EQUITY HOLDERS
  
  Why? Because equity holders receive the proceeds from debt issuance:
  • Face value: $400M
  • Issue price: 98% = $392M (in this problem)
  • Equity receives: $392M in cash
  • Equity gives up: $400M in future claims (in expected value, accounting for refinancing risk)
  • The $8M discount reflects debt holders' required compensation for refinancing and distress risk
  • Therefore, equity bears the cost ex-ante through receiving lower proceeds

Wealth transfer at issuance:
  • If BridgeCorp could eliminate refinancing risk (issue 4-year debt with certainty of no interim rollover):
    - Debt might be issued at par: $400M
    - Equity would receive $400M instead of $392M
    - Equity value would be $8M higher
  • The $8M represents the ex-ante cost of refinancing risk that's borne by equity through reduced proceeds

Numerical example of ex-ante vs ex-post cost allocation:

At issuance (t=0):
  • Equity receives $392M (not $400M)
  • Cost: $8M lower proceeds
  • This compensates debt holders for bearing refinancing risk

At Year 2 (ex-post, if refinancing fails):
  • Fire-sale cost: $80M
  • Split between debt and equity based on firm value
  • But debt was already compensated ex-ante through the discount!
  • This is why debt demanded $8M discount initially

Expected present value of fire-sale cost:
  • Probability: 15%
  • Cost: $80M
  • Occurs at Year 2
  • PV = 0.15 × $80M / (1.0672)²
  • PV = $12M / 1.1388
  • PV ≈ $10.5M

Note: The $8M discount at issuance is less than the $10.5M expected PV of fire-sale costs because:
  • Debt holders bear only part of the fire-sale loss (equity bears the rest)
  • The discount also reflects lost tax shields and other refinancing risk factors
  • Market pricing is forward-looking and risk-adjusted

Question 3: Why might BridgeCorp choose shorter maturity with refinancing risk?

Despite the refinancing risk and associated costs, firms may prefer shorter-maturity debt for several reasons:

Reason 1: Interest Rate Expectations
  • If BridgeCorp expects interest rates to FALL in 2 years:
    - Locking in 4-year debt today means paying current (higher) rates for 4 years
    - Refinancing at Year 2 allows them to capture lower rates for Years 3-4
    - Expected savings from lower future rates may exceed the expected refinancing risk cost
  
  • Example:
    - Current 4-year rate: 6.5%
    - Expected 2-year rate in 2 years: 5.0%
    - Savings in Years 3-4 from refinancing: ~1.5% per year on $400M = $6M/year
    - PV of savings may exceed PV of refinancing risk cost

Reason 2: Flexibility and Financial Slack
  • Shorter maturity gives more frequent opportunities to adjust capital structure
  • Can reduce debt if growth opportunities arise (avoid debt overhang)
  • Can increase debt if tax shields become more valuable
  • Can switch to equity financing if asymmetric information problems ease
  • Maintains strategic flexibility to respond to changing conditions

Reason 3: Match with Asset Duration
  • If BridgeCorp's assets have short duration (e.g., working capital, inventory, receivables):
    - Matching debt maturity to asset maturity reduces risk
    - Long-term debt against short-term assets creates maturity mismatch
    - Short maturity ensures debt comes due when assets mature/liquidate naturally
  • Example: If assets turn over every 2 years, 2-year debt is natural match

Reason 4: Signaling and Information Asymmetry
  • Short-maturity debt signals management's confidence
  • Willingness to face frequent refinancing suggests management believes firm will remain healthy
  • Market interprets this as positive signal about future prospects
  • Long-maturity debt might signal uncertainty or fear of future inability to refinance

Reason 5: Agency Cost Reduction
  • Short maturity gives debt holders more frequent control/monitoring opportunities
  • Reduces risk-shifting and asset substitution problems
  • Equity can't exploit debt holders as easily with short-maturity debt
  • This reduces the risk premium debt holders require, potentially lowering overall cost

Reason 6: Granularity and Refinancing Timing
  • By refinancing at Year 2 instead of Year 4, BridgeCorp gets TWO chances to assess market conditions
  • Can refinance for 2 years at Year 2, then reassess at Year 4
  • Versus: Lock in 4-year debt now with no optionality
  • The option to refinance has value (American option-like feature)

Trade-off Summary:
  • Costs of shorter maturity: Refinancing risk, fire-sale costs, lost tax shields
  • Benefits: Rate flexibility, strategic optionality, asset-liability matching, signaling
  • Optimal choice depends on: Rate expectations, firm's operating characteristics, information asymmetry

Conclusion:
  BridgeCorp's choice of 2+2 structure (refinance at Year 2) versus 4-year bullet represents a conscious trade-off. They're accepting refinancing risk in exchange for flexibility, potential rate savings, and better asset-liability matching. The $1.44M reduction in tax shield NPV (Part B) and the 15% × $80M expected fire-sale cost are prices worth paying if the benefits (rate savings, flexibility) exceed these costs. This is common in practice: many firms maintain "laddered" maturity structures with regular refinancing opportunities rather than locking in ultra-long-term debt.
solution_steps.sanity_check: The fire-sale cost of $80M (20% of $400M debt) is a typical distress cost magnitude in corporate finance literature. The logic that equity bears the cost ex-ante through lower proceeds makes sense because debt holders are forward-looking and price in refinancing risk. The trade-offs between short and long maturity are well-established in the literature (Diamond 1991, Barclay-Smith 1995).

solution_steps.part: Part D - Optimal Maturity Structure Trade-Offs
solution_steps.prompt: What are the key advantages and disadvantages of longer vs. shorter maturity debt, and when is each preferred?
solution_steps.reasoning: Debt maturity choice is a fundamental corporate finance decision that involves balancing multiple competing forces: refinancing risk, flexibility, cost, signaling, and agency problems. The optimal maturity structure depends on firm-specific characteristics, market conditions, and the nature of the firm's assets and growth opportunities.
solution_steps.calculation:
LONGER MATURITY DEBT (e.g., 7-10+ years)

Advantages:

1. Eliminates Refinancing Risk
  • No need to return to debt markets at interim dates
  • Avoids risk of credit market closure or adverse conditions
  • Provides certainty about financing costs for extended period
  • Particularly valuable during credit crises when markets freeze
  • Example: Firms that issued long-term debt before 2008 avoided refinancing crisis

2. Locks in Tax Shield Value
  • If issued when rates are low, captures favorable tax shields for entire maturity
  • Avoids risk of losing tax benefits if refinancing becomes impossible
  • Creates more certain stream of interest deductions
  • Higher present value of tax shields when rates are locked in long-term

3. Reduces Transaction Costs
  • Fewer refinancing events → lower issuance fees, legal costs, underwriting fees
  • One-time cost versus recurring costs of regular refinancing
  • Saves management time and attention
  • Example: If refinancing costs 2% of issue amount, avoiding 2-3 refinancings saves significant value

4. Matches Long-Lived Assets
  • Appropriate for firms with long-duration assets (real estate, infrastructure, utilities)
  • Aligns asset and liability maturities
  • Reduces maturity mismatch risk
  • Example: A power plant with 30-year life should have long-term debt

5. Financial Flexibility During Growth
  • Frees management to focus on operations and investments
  • No near-term refinancing pressure that might force value-destroying actions
  • Can undertake long-term projects without worrying about interim financing
  • Particularly important for R&D-intensive or long-gestation projects

Disadvantages:

1. Higher Interest Rates
  • Term premium: Long-term rates typically > short-term rates (upward-sloping yield curve)
  • Might pay 1-2% more per year for long maturity
  • If rates fall in future, locked into high-cost debt
  • Example: 10-year debt at 7% vs. 2-year debt at 5% → extra 2% per year on $400M = $8M/year

2. Reduced Flexibility to Adjust Capital Structure
  • Can't easily reduce debt if growth opportunities emerge (debt overhang becomes persistent)
  • Can't easily increase debt if tax benefits become more valuable
  • Stuck with capital structure for extended period
  • Prepayment penalties make early retirement expensive

3. Exacerbates Agency Problems
  • Management has longer period to engage in risk-shifting, asset substitution
  • Debt holders face greater risk of being exploited
  • Covenants may be harder to enforce over longer horizons
  • Firm characteristics can change dramatically over 10+ years

4. Call Provisions and Prepayment Penalties
  • If debt is callable, firm pays for the call option through higher coupon
  • If debt is non-callable, firm can't retire it if conditions improve
  • Prepayment penalties can be substantial (e.g., 5-10% of principal)
  • Creates "stranded" debt if firm wants to change capital structure

5. Less Frequent Monitoring
  • Debt holders have fewer opportunities to reassess firm
  • Can't easily adjust terms or walk away if firm deteriorates
  • May demand higher initial rates to compensate for long monitoring horizon
  • Example: A firm might deteriorate significantly in years 5-6, but debt holders are locked in

SHORTER MATURITY WITH ROLLOVER (e.g., 2-3 years, refinancing regularly)

Advantages:

1. Lower Interest Rates Initially
  • Short-term rates typically < long-term rates (when curve is upward-sloping)
  • Can save 1-2% per year initially
  • If rates stay low, continues to save money at each refinancing
  • Example: 2-year at 5% vs. 10-year at 7% → saves $8M/year on $400M

2. Flexibility to Adjust Capital Structure
  • Can reduce debt at each refinancing date if growth opportunities emerge
  • Can increase debt if tax benefits are more valuable
  • Can switch to equity if information asymmetry declines
  • Maintains optionality to respond to changing conditions

3. Benefit from Falling Interest Rates
  • If rates decline over time, captures lower rates at refinancing
  • Has option to refinance at favorable terms
  • Long-term debt would be locked in at higher rates
  • Example: If 2-year rate falls from 5% to 3%, saves 2% for subsequent periods

4. Matches Short-Duration Assets
  • Appropriate for firms with high asset turnover (retail, technology, services)
  • Inventory and receivables turn over quickly → short-term debt is natural match
  • Reduces asset-liability maturity mismatch
  • Example: A retailer with 90-day inventory turns should have short-term financing

5. Signals Quality and Reduces Agency Costs
  • Willingness to face regular refinancing signals management confidence
  • Market interprets as positive signal about prospects
  • Frequent market scrutiny reduces moral hazard
  • Debt holders can walk away if firm deteriorates → disciplines management
  • Reduces risk premium required by debt holders

6. Better Terms Due to Reduced Uncertainty
  • Over 2-3 years, uncertainty about firm value is lower than over 10 years
  • Debt holders face less risk → may accept lower spreads
  • Covenant violations and renegotiations are easier/cheaper
  • Can negotiate more flexible terms knowing refinancing is coming

Disadvantages:

1. Refinancing Risk
  • Must return to market regularly
  • Risk that credit markets are closed or expensive
  • Risk that firm's credit deteriorates and can't refinance at reasonable terms
  • Example: 15% probability of failure at each refinancing → cumulative risk grows

2. Fire-Sale/Distress Costs If Refinancing Fails
  • Forced asset liquidation at distressed prices
  • Costs of 20-40% of debt value are typical
  • Disruption to operations
  • Potential bankruptcy if refinancing fails completely

3. Transaction Costs from Repeated Refinancing
  • Issuance fees, legal costs, underwriting fees at each refinancing
  • If refinancing every 2 years over 10-year horizon → 4-5 refinancings
  • Each costs ~2% of issue amount → cumulative cost is substantial
  • Management time and attention diverted repeatedly

4. Interest Rate Risk
  • If rates RISE over time, forced to refinance at higher rates
  • Example: If 2-year rate rises from 5% to 8%, pays 3% more for subsequent periods
  • Versus long-term debt would have locked in original low rate
  • Creates earnings volatility from changing interest expenses

5. Rollover Pressure May Force Bad Decisions
  • When refinancing is imminent, management might:
    - Reject positive-NPV projects (debt overhang)
    - Cut dividends/repurchases to hoard cash
    - Take excessive risk to improve near-term performance (risk-shifting)
    - Avoid negative but truthful disclosure to ensure successful refinancing
  • These distortions can destroy significant value

WHEN TO PREFER EACH:

Prefer LONGER MATURITY when:
  1. Firm has long-duration assets (real estate, infrastructure, utilities, heavy manufacturing)
  2. Operating environment is stable and predictable
  3. Interest rates are currently LOW (favorable time to lock in long-term)
  4. Firm values financial stability and certainty highly
  5. Credit markets may become difficult to access (e.g., firm has high leverage, or expects industry stress)
  6. Transaction costs of repeated refinancing are high
  7. Firm wants to pursue long-term investments without refinancing pressure

Example firms: Utilities, pipelines, REITs, mature industrial companies

Prefer SHORTER MATURITY when:
  1. Firm has short-duration, high-turnover assets (retail inventory, tech equipment, working capital)
  2. Operating environment is uncertain or changing rapidly
  3. Interest rates are currently HIGH (expect them to fall, want option to refinance at lower rates)
  4. Firm has high growth opportunities and values flexibility
  5. Firm is high-quality with reliable access to credit markets
  6. Asset substitution / agency problems are severe (need frequent debt holder monitoring)
  7. Firm wants to signal confidence in future prospects

Example firms: Technology, retail, high-growth startups (if they can access debt at all)

EMPIRICAL EVIDENCE:
  • Large, rated firms with tangible assets → longer maturity (7-10 years average)
  • Smaller, growth firms → shorter maturity (3-5 years average)
  • Debt maturity is typically 30-70% of asset maturity
  • Firms "ladder" maturities: stagger debt across multiple maturities to balance trade-offs
  • During credit crisis (2008-09), firms with maturing debt faced severe refinancing difficulties → pushed many toward longer maturities post-crisis

OPTIMAL STRATEGY: LADDERED MATURITY STRUCTURE
  • Instead of choosing all-long or all-short, firms often "ladder" maturities
  • Example: $400M debt split into:
    - $100M maturing in 2 years
    - $100M maturing in 4 years  
    - $100M maturing in 6 years
    - $100M maturing in 8 years
  • This provides:
    - Regular refinancing opportunities (flexibility)
    - But only 25% of debt matures at any point (limits refinancing risk)
    - Blended cost between short and long rates
    - Smooths out interest rate risk
  • Many sophisticated firms use this approach (GE, IBM, large banks)
solution_steps.sanity_check: The trade-offs presented align with academic literature (Diamond 1991, Barclay-Smith 1995, Guedes-Opler 1996) and industry practice. The insight that firms should match debt maturity to asset maturity is well-established. The point about laddered structures representing an optimal compromise is consistent with observed corporate behavior.

key_insights: Refinancing risk reduces tax shield value by creating uncertainty about the firm's ability to maintain debt in future periods. The 15% refinancing failure probability reduces Years 3-4 tax shield NPV by exactly 15%.

Refinancing risk is a distinct form of financial distress, separate from operational default risk. It creates liquidity crises even when the firm is operationally healthy, forcing value-destructive asset fire sales.

Fire-sale costs of 20% of debt value ($80M on $400M debt) are borne ex-ante by equity through lower debt proceeds at issuance. Debt holders demand compensation for refinancing risk through discounts or higher yields.

Firms rationally choose shorter maturity debt despite refinancing risk when the benefits (rate flexibility, strategic optionality, signaling) outweigh the costs (expected fire-sale losses, reduced tax shield certainty).

Longer maturity debt locks in refinancing certainty and tax shields but sacrifices flexibility and may lock in high rates. Shorter maturity provides flexibility and initially lower rates but creates refinancing and interest rate risk.

Optimal debt maturity depends on firm characteristics: Long-duration asset firms prefer long maturity; high-turnover asset firms prefer short maturity. Growth firms value flexibility; stable firms value certainty.
Laddered maturity structures (staggering debt across multiple maturities) provide a middle ground, combining refinancing flexibility with limited rollover risk at any single point.
Refinancing risk is most dangerous when large amounts of debt mature simultaneously ('maturity walls'), especially if this coincides with market stress or firm-specific difficulties.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to adjust the tax shield discount rate when calculating cost of debt from issue price—must use the promised YTM of 6.72%, not the coupon rate of 6%
Applying refinancing risk probability to Years 1-2 tax shields—these are certain since the original bond is outstanding; only Years 3-4 are at risk
Thinking fire-sale costs are borne only by equity at the time of failure—they're priced into debt at issuance through lower proceeds, so equity bears the cost ex-ante
Confusing refinancing risk with default risk—refinancing failure is a liquidity crisis that can occur even when the firm is operationally healthy and solvent
Believing shorter maturity is always worse because of refinancing risk—ignoring the offsetting benefits of flexibility, lower initial rates, and optionality
Not recognizing that maturity choice should match asset duration—short-maturity debt is appropriate for firms with high asset turnover like retailers
Assuming the simple tax shield formula τ×D applies with refinancing risk—must probability-weight future shields by continuation probability
Thinking longer maturity always provides stability—ignoring that it locks the firm into a capital structure that may become suboptimal if conditions change

Initial Bond Issue:
• Face value: $400M

Market Conditions:
